content.question: Figure 1 shows the kinetic energy as a function of time for a <math alttext="2 kilograms " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> object that is released from rest and falls toward Earth’s surface. Figure 2 shows the kinetic energy as a function of time for a <math alttext="5 kilograms " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> object that is released from rest and falls toward Earth’s surface. Both objects are released simultaneously from the same height. How much does the gravitational potential energy of the object-object-Earth system change from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
